results.title: You don't fool me
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Shows how a social psychological experiment is designed, conducted and analysed. The experiment is a test to see if non-verbal behaviour gives clues as to whether a person is being deceptive - the hypothesis being that the face will not give clues to deception, but the hands and feet will. One of a series of a third level course from the Faculty of Social Science Open University. The purpose is to provide insight into social behaviour and experience. The essential focus is on theories, findings, and methods of social psychology.

results.title: You can help - throw it here
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man builds - man destroys”.
In the past we have burnt and buried waste but today such solutions are inadequate. Here, retrieval recycling, and other environmentally positive forms of waste disposal, including “Mount Trashmore” - a recreational park complete with ski-run, built with waste from neighbouring communities - are examined

results.title: You can go a long way!
results.creator_credit: San Life Assurance Co of Canada and Donald Wilder
results.brief_description: Designed to allow students to explore, in their own way, the reasons why it is wise to finish school, and get as much training and education as possible before looking for a job. Tells in a light way what parents and teachers sometimes knock themselves out trying to prove: that competition is keen in the bread-and -butter world and that the best jobs go to the candidate with the best qualifications.

results.title: You can do it!
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Michael E. Bernard. This video is designed to aid students (and others) in developing the skills and essential attitudes necessary for success in school and happiness in life. The video addresses issues such as goal setting, time management, attitudes, self-confidence, self-motivation, exam anxiety and relationships.

results.title: You Can Do It Too!
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Diane O'Connor
results.brief_description: A character called “x”, who is neither male nor female, points out all the opportunities available to people when gender is made irrelevant. Shows how role stereotyping begins at birth and carries through into school and work. Shows men and women working and finding fulfilment in non-traditional areas. The band playing towards the end of the film features the now ABC political journalist, Fran Kelly, in an unfamiliar guise.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Diane O’Connor

results.title: You can do anything
results.creator_credit: Australia. Dept. of Employment, Education and Training, Film Australia and Aviva Ziegler
results.brief_description: The Kirinara Hostel in N.S.W. offers an educational program specifically designed for young Aboriginal and Islander people. The video focuses on students at the hostel and includes interviews with ex-students who have pursued careers in a diverse range of fields including law, teaching, football and dance. The graduates stress the importance of individuals setting realistic goals for themselves as well as the need for Aboriginal education support schemes to assist young Aboriginal people to achieve their full educational potential.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australia. Dept. of Employment, Education and Training, Film Australia and Aviva Ziegler

results.title: You can count on me
results.creator_credit: Shooting Gallery, Cappa Productions, Hart Sharp Entertainment, Barbara de Fina, Jeffrey Sharp, Larry Meistrich, John N. Hart and Kenneth Lonergan
results.brief_description: You can count on me is a family reunion drama that contains impressive performances full of nuance and has an adroit observational tone. The original screenplay (by director Kenneth Lonergan) veers away from cliche and pat conclusions, imbuing the characters with a realistic quality. Sammy and Terry are orphaned at a young age when their parents are killed in a car accident. As adults, the siblings are estranged, having made divergent choices. Sammy is a single parent with an eight-year-old son, Rudy, living in the house she was brought up in, working in a bank. She lives by a strict moral code, bound by religion and duty, but is entirely capable of hypocrisy and self-delusion. Terry, by contrast, is a wild loner, full of rage, self-destructive by nature but charming in his own humorous way. He doesn’t believe in Sammy’s ordered conservative life and inadvertently challenges this, creating chaos with his presence. It is Terry and Rudy’s strengthening relationship that acts as a catalyst, causing an irrevocable torrent of truths that upend the family dynamics. The personal and familial dilemmas contained within the script are identifiable and the film sensitively deals with themes of oppression and personal choice. Cast includes: Laura Linney, Matthew Broderick, Mark Ruffalo, Rory Culkin.
